subject: RE: [junit] Gathering and displaying supplemental information about 	test failures.
msgSnippet: You might consider extending/changing/refactoring JUnit itself using github. There you can fork JUnit itself and submit your idea for inclusion for everyone.
messageBody:
You might consider extending/changing/refactoring JUnit itself using github.

There you can fork JUnit itself and submit your idea for inclusion for everyone. It is a very easy system. Yet, Kent and David do an excellent job keeping the code consistent. (Enhancements are considered, but there is a high bar for inclusion into the code base.)

With all that said, I think David Saff response covers your initial question.

Big Mike

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Sunburned Surveyor
Sent: Friday, November 20, 2009 1:22 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Gathering and displaying supplemental information about test failures.



Mike,

I've never seen it. I am interested, but ultimately we are looking for a
solution that will work outside of Eclipse. We are working on an open source
library, and we can't know what IDE/build environment other contributors
will be using.

Maybe if I get something worked up they would consider making it a
supplemental part of JUnit. In the worst case, I'll make a distro of my code
available on SourceForge.

Landon

> Subject: [junit] Gathering and displaying supplemental information about
> test failures.
>
>
> I have a question about the options for gathering and displaying
> supplemental information about test failures. Please allow me to
> illustrate my question with a simple example.
>
> I've got a class called Coordinate that represents a point in a 3D
> coordinate system. I've overloaded the toString method of this class
> to write out the X, Y, and Z values of the coordinate in a simple
> String. Now I want to test my toString method using JUnit.
>
> If the Coordinate.toString test method fails (because the string was
> not constructed in the correct format) I would like to provide the
> programmer running the test with a copy of the incorrect string, since
> it provides valuable clues about what is broken with the method under
> test. I typically do this by placing System.err.println statements in
> my test method. However, I realize that using System.err.println isn't
> the most portable or elegant way to provide this information to the
> programmer executing the test.
>
> What I really want is a GUI that allows the programmer to select a
> failed test from a list of failed tests, and then to view supplemental
> test data I provide him/her.
>
> I was thinking I could do this by completing the following tasks:
>
> - Implementing the RunListener interface in JUnit.
> - Create an extension of Exception that could contain a HashMap of
> simple parameters and that would be passed to the constructor of a
> Failure object from within a test.
> - Creating Failure objects in my tests that contain the supplemental
> failrure data.
> - Passing these failure objects to my RunListener implementaiton.
> - Creating a FailureProcessor class that displays a GUI with the
> information in my RunListener implemenation to show the programmer
> executing my tests the supplemental failure data as described above.
> (FailureProcessor would be an interface so that you could do different
> things with the supplemental failure data, not just show it in a GUI.)
>
> Before I begin this work, I wanted to ask if there was a better way to
> do this. I know I could use a logging framework from within my test
> method, but I really want to work within the JUnut framework, not
> outside of it. I also want a nice little GUI, not a log file.
>
> How are other programmers handling instances when they want to display
> supplemental data on failed tests? Does my approach sound reasonable?
>
> The Sunburned Surveyor
